definition: Hua Tuo (?-208), famous doctor at the end of Han Dynasty
magnificent/splendid/flowery
old variant of 花[hua1]/flower
Mt Hua 華山|华山 in Shaanxi/surname Hua
abbr. for China
carry on the back

sentences.english: When they woke up, we went to climb the park again.
sentences.chinese: 当她们醒来之后，我们又去爬华佗山公园了。

sentences.english: When treating illness, he even utilized psychological methods.
sentences.chinese: 在治疗疾病时，华佗甚至已经运用了心理疗法。

sentences.english: I took my daughter to HuaTuo Mountain Park this morning.
sentences.chinese: 今天早上，我带女儿去爬华佗山公园了。

sentences.english: Objective To investigate the efficacy of Huatuo Jaji points for treating chronic gastritis patients.
sentences.chinese: 目的观察采用华佗夹脊穴治疗慢性胃炎的疗效。

sentences.english: After washing the clothes and having breakfast, we went to the Hua Tuo Mountain Park again.
sentences.chinese: 洗完衣服吃过早餐之后，我们又去爬华佗山公园了。

sentences.english: I have no fear.” Hua cut the skin and flesh open and scraped the bone with scalpel.
sentences.chinese: 华佗切开肉皮，用刀刮骨。

sentences.english: Then he gave orders to hold a dinner for Hua Tuo.
Hua Tuo attached importance to therapy. He also emphasized prevention.
sentences.chinese: 华佗在医疗上有突出贡献，同时强调预防。

sentences.english: Nobody could save him even though Hua Tuo should come here.
sentences.chinese: 即使华佗在世也救不了他。

definition: Hua Tuo (c. 140-208), ancient Chinese physician from the Eastern Han period
Sun Simiao (c. 581-682), doctor and herbalist of the Sui and Tang dynasty, author of Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold 千金要方[Qian1 jin1 Yao4 fang1]

Cao Cao (155-220), famous statesman and general at the end of Han, noted poet and calligrapher, later warlord, founder and first king of Cao Wei 曹魏, father of Emperor Cao Pi 曹丕/the main villain of novel the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义
Dong Feng, doctor during Three Kingdoms period, famous for refusing fees and requesting that his patients plant apricot trees instead
Qin Yueren (407-310 BC), Warring States physician known for his medical skills

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
秦越人[Qin2 Yue4 ren2] (407-310 BC), Warring States physician known for his medical skills, nicknamed Bian Que after the earliest known Chinese physician allegedly from the 黃帝|黄帝[Huang2 di4] era
courtesy name of Zhuge Liang 諸葛亮|诸葛亮[Zhu1 ge3 Liang4]

Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama
Xun Yu (163-212), brilliant strategist, advisor of Cao Cao in Three Kingdoms
Lü Meng (178-219), general of the southern state of Wu
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty
Luo Guanzhong (c. 1330-c. 1400), author of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms and other works
Li Shizhen (1518-1593), Ming botanist and pharmacologist, author of Compendium of Medical Herbs 本草綱目|本草纲目[Ben3 cao3 Gang1 mu4]
healer/physician/medical man/doctor (esp. of TCM)
Zhao Yun (-229), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
